posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Hey guys, Something strange is happening with the limelight when I deploy the code. So I am putting the id of the April tag detected by our limelight on the shuffleboard as a widget, information which I get straight from the limelight pipeline. In my code, for my April tag aligning method, I have a check to see if the id of the current April Tag is > -1 (meaning that there is an April tag in view). However, this code seems to be behaving inconsistently when I deploy the code: Sometimes, even when the widget on the shuffleboard shows the id of the April tag in view, the function in the code returns that there is no April tags detected, forcing me to redeploy the code again before it works normally. Since it works fine after deploying a second time, I’m assuming my code should be working but I’m not really sure. Here is the function I’m referring to in my code: CrescendoCodeMigrated2025/CrescendoCodeUpdatedImported2025/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/Swerve.java at main · DesteoyerRZSS/CrescendoCodeMigrated2025 · GitHub

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Some suggestions that might not help this particular problem but you should always check for the validity of a reading with tv and why would you send a 0 in your .getInteger(0); if you allow 0 to be a valid tag id? And I don’t think that 0 is a valid tag this FRC season.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: What version of shuffleboard are you using?

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: I’m not sure how to check the version for the shuffleboard. I can see my driver station is version 25.0 if that helps at all.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: That’s helpful, I didn’t realize that’s what tv was supposed to  represent. Also, I was mainly focused on April tag alignment and detection in general, but I will definitely add a check to see if the tag is valid on the field after I get this working. I didn’t notice that I was returning zero for the default value and I will also definitely fix that. Thanks for the suggestions!

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: @Joe_Ross @SLAB-Mr.Thomas Update on the issue. It turns out that it isn’t just happening sporadically. For some reason, the curr_tag_in_view being used by the move to April tag command isn’t being updated after the code is deployed. When the code is deployed when the robot is facing the April tag, the curr_tag_in_view is set to that tag’s value and doesn’t change even when I turn away from the April tag. The opposite happens when initialized away from the April tag. I’m not sure why this is happening though.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Rzheng1232:

doesn’t change

That’s how it’s supposed to work - or - Java did what you told it to do and not what you wanted it to do.

Command factories are an important tool in Command-Based in order to make a command but there are restrictions.  Everything above the return statement is executed only once when the command is created - usually at the beginning of the program. This is what you are experiencing.

Everything in the return statement is the command to be used and it is essentially fixed except the class field variables are available. Also, you can use a Supplier to dynamically acquire new data. This is mostly how Command-Based works - there are other less commonly used techniques such as making a new command in your own class. This may be a somewhat simplistic view of Command-Based but should be enough detail to get you going again.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Ahh, ok. That makes a lot of sense. I have experience with java but I’m still relatively new to command based, so I didn’t realize that when writing the function. Thank you so much!

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: It’s displayed on the splash screen when starting shuffleboard and also in the about menu.
